00020  @page linux_user Linux Userspace on the OCTEON
00021 
00022 @section linux_user_intro 1. Introduction
00023 
00024 Userspace applications on OCTEON have some added options compared to
00025 other processors running Linux. This document contains an overview of
00026 these options for both 32 and 64 bit applications. Along with this document,
00027 the @ref linux document adds additional reference material.
00028 
00029 This document provides detailed information on the following aspects of
00030 userspace on the Cavium Inc. OCTEON processor:
00031 
00032 - @ref linux_user_intro
00033 - @ref linux_user_abi
00034 - @ref linux_user_memory_map
00035 - @ref linux_user_unaligned
00036 - @ref linux_user_building
00037 - @ref linux_user_building_cvmx
00038 - @ref linux_user_cvmx
00039 - @ref linux_user_checklist
00040 - @ref linux_user_passthrough
00041 - @ref linux_user_files
00042 - @ref linux_user_bootmem
00043 - @ref linux_user_debugging
00044 - @ref linux_user_flash
00045 - @ref linux_user_mass_storage_flash
00046 - @ref linux_user_serial
00047 - @ref linux_user_hugetlb
00048 - @ref linux_user_htlbremap
00049 - @ref linux_user_schedtool
00050 
00051 @section linux_user_abi 2. Userspace ABIs
00052 
00053 The Linux kernel supports three different application binary interfaces
00054 (ABIs) for Mips64 and above processors. These ABIs provide different
00055 tradeoffs for applications. Here is a short summary of the three types:
00056 
00057 - O32 ABI supports all Mips processors. The resulting program binary is
00058 in ELF32 format whose symbol table is in .mdebug format.  Up to four
00059 registers ($a0..$a3) can be used for passing integer arguments. All
00060 registers are treated as 32 bits. 64 bit types are split into two
00061 separate registers.
00062 
00063 - N64 ABI supports the Mips4 and higher processors. The resulting program
00064 binary is in ELF64 format whose symbol table is in DWARF format.  Up to
00065 eight registers ($a0..$a7) can be used for passing integer arguments. All
00066 registers are 64 bits wide and full 64 bit operations are supported.
00067 
00068 - N32 ABI supports the Mips4 and higher processors. The resulting program
00069 binary is in ELF32 format whose symbol table is in DWARF format.
00070 The N32 calling convention is the same as the N64 calling convention.
00071 Register are 64 bits wide and full 64 bit operations are supported.
00072 
00073 Historically, the most heavily used ABI is O32. O32 is used by most
00074 Mips Linux distributions including Gentoo, Debian, and the Redhat Mips
00075 port. The newer ABIs (N64, N32) are used primarily by SGI. These newer
00076 ABIs provide many performance benefits over the older O32 ABI. The
00077 following table highlights some of the differences as they relate to
00078 OCTEON.
00079 
00080 <table>
00081     <tr><td></td>           <td>O32</td>    <td>N32</td>    <td>N64</td></tr>
00082     <tr><td>int</td>        <td>32bits</td> <td>32bits</td> <td>32bits</td></tr>
00083     <tr><td>long</td>       <td>32bits</td> <td>32bits</td> <td>64bits</td></tr>
00084     <tr><td>long long</td>  <td>64bits</td> <td>64bits</td> <td>64bits</td></tr>
00085     <tr><td>pointer</td>    <td>32bits</td> <td>32bits</td> <td>64bits</td></tr>
00086     <tr><td>regsiter</td>   <td>32bits</td> <td>64bits</td> <td>64bits</td></tr>
00087 </table>
00088 
00089 Code requiring more than 2GB of memory or direct access to OCTEON
00090 hardware should use the N64 ABI. Code requiring many data
00091 structures dealing with pointers, but requiring only occasional
00092 hardware access should use the N32 ABI. Some older applications
00093 and binaries may still use the O32 ABI, but it is recommended that
00094 they be upgraded to the N32 ABI.
00095 
00096 The Linux cross compiler shipped as part of the OCTEON SDK supports
00097 building code for both the N32 and N64 ABI. If the @b -mabi=n32 option is
00098 not specified, the default is N64 (@b -mabi=64).
00099 
00100 @section linux_user_memory_map 3. Userspace Memory Map
00101 
00102 The userspace memory map is configurable through the Linux config
00103 interface to support multiple option for different types of user
00104 environments. Here is a list of the relevant kernel config options:
00105 
00106 @verbatim
00107     Machine selection  --->
00108         (0) Number of extra L1 cache lines reserved for CVMSEG memory
00109             Allow User space to access hardware IO directly (Per process)  --->
00110                  ( ) Allowed
00111                  (X) Per process
00112                  ( ) Disabled
00113             Allow User space to access memory directly (Per process)  --->
00114                  ( ) Allowed
00115                  (X) Per process
00116                  ( ) Disabled
00117         (512)   Memory to reserve for user processes shared region (MB)
00118 @endverbatim
00119 
00120 - Number of extra L1 cache lines reserved for CVMSEG memory
00121 (CONFIG_CAVIUM_OCTEON_EXTRA_CVMSEG)<br> CVMSEG LM is a segment that
00122 accesses portions of the dcache as a local memory; the larger CVMSEG
00123 is, the smaller the cache is.  This selects the size of CVMSEG LM in
00124 cache blocks. The legal range is from zero to 54 cache blocks
00125 (i.e. CVMSEG LM is between zero and 6192 bytes).  The kernel will
00126 automatically reserve several cache lines of CVMSEG LM, this
00127 option is used to request additional lines beyond what is normally
00128 required for the kernel to function.
00129 
00130 - Per-process access control for user programs to access hardware IO directly
00131 (CONFIG_CAVIUM_OCTEON_USER_IO_PER_PROCESS)<br>
00132  This option provides the ability to dynamically enable/disable access
00133  to the OCTEON hardware IO addresses (0x8001000000000000 - 0x8001ffffffffffff)
00134  with sysmips() system call. sysmips() only enables this access for the
00135  calling process.
00136 
00137 - Allow all user space processes to access hardware IO directly
00138 (CONFIG_CAVIUM_OCTEON_USER_IO)<br>
00139 Allows all user applications to directly access the OCTEON hardware
00140 IO addresses (0x8001000000000000 - 0x8001ffffffffffff). This allows high
00141 performance networking applications to run in user space with minimal
00142 performance penalties. This also means a user application can bring
00143 down the entire system. Only use this option on embedded devices
00144 where all user applications are strictly controlled.
00145 
00146 - Per-process access control for user programs to access memory directly
00147 (CONFIG_CAVIUM_OCTEON_USER_MEM_PER_PROCESS)<br>
00148  This option provides the ability to dynamically enable/disable access
00149  to the XKPHYS addresses corresponding to memory, with sysmips() system
00150  call. sysmips() only enables this access for the calling process.
00151 
00152 - Allow all User space to access memory directly
00153 (CONFIG_CAVIUM_OCTEON_USER_MEM)<br>
00154 Allows user applications to use XKPHYS addresses directly to memory.
00155 This allows user space direct access to shared memory not in use by
00156 Linux. This memory is suitable for use with the OCTEON hardware.
00157 Cavium simple executive applications also share this memory. Since
00158 this bypass all of the Linux memory protection, only use this option
00159 on embedded devices where all user applications are strictly
00160 controlled.
00161 
00162 - Memory to reserve for user processes shared region (MB)
00163 (CONFIG_CAVIUM_RESERVE32)<br>
00164 Reserve a shared memory region for user processes to use for hardware
00165 memory buffers. This is required for 32bit applications to be able to
00166 send and receive packets directly. Applications access this memory by
00167 memory mapping /dev/mem for the addresses in /proc/octeon_info. For
00168 optimal performance, keep this size a power of 2.
00169 
00170 @b Process @b Memory @b Map
00171 
00172 The following table shows an example memory map.
00173 
00174 <table>
00175 <tr>
00176     <td><dfn>0x8001ffffffffffff<br>0x8001000000000000</dfn></td>
00177     <td>64bit</td>
00178     <td>Hardware IO addresses. Only accessible if CONFIG_CAVIUM_OCTEON_USER_IO.</td>
00179 </tr>
00180 <tr>
00181     <td><dfn>0x8000ffffffffffff<br>0x8000000000000000</dfn></td>
00182     <td>64bit</td>
00183     <td>64bit XKPHYS address bypassing TLB. Only accessible if CONFIG_CAVIUM_OCTEON_USER_MEM.</td>
00184 </tr>
00185 <tr>
00186     <td><dfn>0xffffffffffffffff<br>0xffffffff80000000</dfn></td>
00187     <td>32bit</td>
00188     <td>Kernel mode addresses only - Not available to userspace.</td>
00189 </tr>
00190 <tr>
00191     <td><dfn>0x3fffffffffffffff<br>0x0000000000000000</dfn></td>
00192     <td>64bit</td>
00193     <td>Normal 64bit application address space.</td>
00194 </tr>
00195 <tr>
00196     <td><dfn>linux_mem32_max<br>linux_mem32_min</dfn></td>
00197     <td>32bit</td>
00198     <td>Shared memory area reserved by calling cvmx_bootmem_alloc.
00199         Only accessible if CONFIG_CAVIUM_RESERVE32.</td>
00200 </tr>
00201 <tr>
00202     <td><dfn>0x000000007fff8000<br>0x0000000000000000</dfn></td>
00203     <td>32bit</td>
00204     <td>Normal application address space.</td>
00205 </tr>
00206 </table>
00207 
00208 @section linux_user_unaligned 4. Unaligned memory access
00209 
00210 OCTEON supports three ways of handling unaligned accesses to memory.
00211 
00212 - Address Exception - In default Mips compatibility mode, an unaligned
00213 access causes an address alignment exception. The Linux kernel then fixes
00214 the offending access in software and returns from the exception. This can
00215 take in the order of 1us per access exception.
00216 
00217 - Special unaligned instructions - OCTEON can support additional
00218 instructions (ulw, usw, uld, usd) specifically handling unaligned accesses.
00219 Since the opcodes for these instructions replace the Mips standard lwl and
00220 lwr instructions, they are disable under Linux to maintain full Mips
00221 userspace compatibility.
00222 
00223 - Hardware fixups of unaligned access - OCTEON also supports automatic
00224 fixups for unaligned accesses by the hardware. These fixups add an
00225 additional 6 cycles to the load/store, but are far faster than the standard
00226 Mips exception handling.
00227 
00228 OCTEON automatic hardware fixups under Linux userspace is controlled by a
00229 kernel configuration option. By default this option is on. You may need to
00230 disable this option if you're running old Mips code that assumes unaligned
00231 accesses cause exceptions. The kernel option is under:
00232 
00233 @verbatim
00234     Machine selection  --->
00235     [*] Enable hardware fixups of unaligned loads and stores
00236 @endverbatim
00237 
00238 @section linux_user_building 5. Building Applications
00239 
00240 @subsection building_using_cross_tools 5.1 Building Applications Using OCTEON Cross toolchain
00241 
00242 The OCTEON SDK supplies a i686 to OCTEON cross compiler. The compiler
00243 supports glibc, pthreads, and c++. Here is an example to compile hello
00244 world.
00245 
00246 hello_world.c
00247 @code
00248     #include <stdio.h>
00249     int main(int argc, const char *argv[])
00250     {
00251         printf("Hello world!\n");
00252         return 0;
00253     }
00254 @endcode
00255 
00256 Compile:
00257 @verbatim
00258     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-gcc -mabi=64 -o hello_world hello_world.c
00259 or
00260     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-gcc -mabi=n32 -o hello_world hello_world.c
00261 @endverbatim
00262 
00263 Here is a list of the support commands:
00264 @verbatim
00265     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-addr2line
00266     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-ar
00267     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-as
00268     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-c++
00269     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-c++filt
00270     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-cpp
00271     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-g++
00272     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-gcc
00273     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-gcov
00274     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-ld
00275     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-nm
00276     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-objcopy
00277     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-objdump
00278     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-ranlib
00279     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-readelf
00280     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-size
00281     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-strings
00282     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-strip
00283 @endverbatim
00284 
00285 @subsection building_using_native_tools 5.2 Building Applications Using OCTEON Native Tools
00286 
00287 The OCTEON SDK provides Linux Native tools to build user space applications
00288 on OCTEON. The Linux Native tools are under
00289 OCTEON-SDK/tools/mips64-octeon-linux-gnu/sys-root directory. These tools
00290 are available in Debian under /usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools
00291 directory. Only gdb, gdbserver, gprof are included when Kernel is built
00292 with busybox.
00293 
00294 To use Linux native tools when Kernel is built with busybox mount
00295 OCTEON-SDK/tools/mips64-octeon-linux-gnu/sys-root directory as
00296 mentioned below.
00297 
00298 On your host export the file system
00299 
00300 @verbatim
00301 # /etc/init.d/nfs start
00302 # exportfs -o rw,no_root_squash *:/usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools/mips64-octeon-linux-gnu/sys-root
00303 @endverbatim
00304 
00305 On OCTEON after booting Linux Kernel
00306 
00307 @verbatim
00308 # modprobe octeon-ethernet
00309 # ifconfig eth0 <ip_address>
00310 # mount -o nolock host_ip_address:/usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools/mips64-octeon-linux-gnu/sys-root /mnt
00311 # ln -s /mnt/usr/include /usr
00312 # ln -s /mnt/usr/lib /usr
00313 # cd /usr/lib32; ln -s /mnt/usr/lib32/*.a .
00314 # cd /usr/lib32; ln -s /mnt/usr/lib32/*.o .
00315 # cd /usr/lib64; ln -s /mnt/usr/lib64/*.a .
00316 # cd /usr/lib64; ln -s /mnt/usr/lib64/*.o .
00317 # cd /usr/bin; ln -s /mnt/usr/bin/* .
00318 @endverbatim
00319 
00320 To compile and run the user space applications for the hello_world.c
00321 example, mentioned in section 5.1
00322 
00323 @verbatim
00324     gcc -mabi=64 -o hello_world hello_world.c
00325     ./hello_world
00326     Hello World!
00327 or
00328     gcc -mabi=n32 -o hello_world hello_world.c
00329     ./hello_world
00330     Hello World!
00331 @endverbatim
00332 
00333 @subsection building_for_octeon2 5.3 Optimizing Applications for OCTEON II and OCTEON III
00334 
00335 The OCTEON II processor has several new machine instructions, that if
00336 utilized, can improve the performance of an application.  If it is
00337 known that an application binary will only be used on an OCTEON II
00338 processor, there are several compilation and system configuration
00339 changes that can be made to take advantage of these new instructions.
00340 The OCTEON III processor adds hardware floating point instructions,
00341 that if utilized, can improve the performance of applications that use
00342 a lot of floating point math.
00343 
00344 @subsubsection use_octeon2_dynamic_libs 5.3.1 Use OCTEON II optimized runtime libraries.
00345 
00346 The glibc dynamic linker will automatically select OCTEON II
00347 optimized libraries, if they are present, when running on a
00348 compatible system.  When running on an OCTEON II system, the
00349 directories /lib32/octeon2, /lib64/octeon2, /usr/lib32/octeon2,
00350 and /usr/lib64/octeon2 will be searched for runtime libraries
00351 first.  If a needed library is present in one of these places
00352 it will be used in preference to the standard OCTEON/OCTEON
00353 Plus libraries in /lib32, /lib64, /usr/lib32 and /usr/lib64.
00354 
00355 From the embedded_rootfs directory these can be selected:
00356 
00357 @verbatim
00358     [*] octeon-libraries-n32
00359     [*] octeon2-libraries-n32
00360     [*] octeon3-libraries-n32
00361     --- octeon-libraries-64
00362     [*] octeon2-libraries-64
00363     [*] octeon3-libraries-64 
00364 @endverbatim
00365 
00366 @subsubsection use_octeon2_code_generation 5.3.2 Cause GCC to generate OCTEON II machine instructions.
00367 
00368 Compile:
00369 @verbatim
00370     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-gcc -march=octeon2 -mabi=64 -O3 -o hello_world hello_world.c
00371 or
00372     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-gcc -march=octeon2 -mabi=n32 -O3 -o hello_world hello_world.c
00373 @endverbatim
00374 
00375 Note: Applications built in this manner will not work on OCTEON
00376 and OCTEON Plus processors.  Any attempt to do this will likely
00377 result in the application being killed by the kernel with an
00378 illegal instruction exception (SIGILL).
00379 
00380 @subsubsection use_octeon3_code_generation 5.3.3 Cause GCC to generate OCTEON III machine instructions and use hardware floating point.
00381 
00382 Compile:
00383 @verbatim
00384     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-gcc -march=octeon3 -mabi=64 -O3 -o hello_world hello_world.c
00385 or
00386     mips64-octeon-linux-gnu-gcc -march=octeon3 -mabi=n32 -O3 -o hello_world hello_world.c
00387 @endverbatim
00388 
00389 The runtime libraries for programs build this way are located in
00390 /lib64-fp and /usr/lib64-fp, or /lib32-fp and /usr/lib32-fp
00391 
00392 Note: Applications built in this manner will not work on OCTEON and
00393 OCTEON Plus processors.  Any attempt to do this will likely result in
00394 the application being killed by the kernel with an illegal instruction
00395 exception (SIGILL).  Also when run on OCTEON II processors, any
00396 floating point instructions will have to be emulated by the operating
00397 system kernel, which is slow.
00398 
00399 @section linux_user_building_cvmx 6. Building Simple Executive Applications
00400 
00401 The make system for simple executive applications supports building
00402 N64 Linux userspace applications in addition to the normal standalone
00403 applications. In order to build for Linux, the "make" variable
00404 @b OCTEON_TARGET must be defined to the ABI to use. The valid options are
00405 @b linux_64.
00406 
00407 @verbatim
00408     $ make OCTEON_TARGET=linux_64
00409 @endverbatim
00410 
00411 @section linux_user_cvmx 7. Running Simple Executive Applications under Linux
00412 
00413 The CVMX library provides the same shared memory and process model under
00414 Linux as found in standalone applications. Before the main application
00415 starts executing, the simple executive sets up the CVMX_SHARED region and
00416 forks processes for each core.
00417 
00418 In detail, CVMX_SHARED is implemented as shared memory region mapped over
00419 the CVMX_SHARED variables. First, @b shm_open() is used to create a shared
00420 memory region of the same size as the CVMX_SHARED section. The contents of
00421 CVMX_SHARED is then copied into the shared region. Finally the shared
00422 region is memory mapped over the existing CVMX_SHARED variables using
00423 @b mmap(). In order for @b shm_open() to work, the Linux @b tmpfs
00424 filesystem must be mounted at @b /dev/shm.
00425 
00426 @note Linux simple executive applications must be statically linked. All
00427 CVMX_SHARED variables must be resolved into a single section. This can only
00428 be guaranteed to happen for statically linked applications.
00429 
00430 After the shared region is setup, @b fork() is used to create a copy of
00431 the process for each SMP core. Each forked process is then tied to a
00432 specific core using @b sched_setaffinity(). Once all processes are ready
00433 and synchronized using cvmx_coremask_barrier_sync(), control transfers to
00434 @b appmain(int argc, const char *argv[]).
00435 
00436 The Linux userspace startup code can be found in "cvmx-app-init-linux.c".
00437 
00438 @note simprintf() performs quite differently under Linux. Instead of using
00439 a simulator specific trap to print the message, it uses the standard C
00440 library. In order to enforce some ordering, each simprintf() is locked
00441 using a cvmx_spinlock_t. simprintf() may be removed in the future and
00442 should be considered @b deprecated.
00443 
00444 Linux simple executive application must be linked with simple executive
00445 and use the cvmx-shared-linux.ld linker script. See the crypto
00446 example for a Makefile to use as a template.
00447 
00448 @code
00449     $ cd examples/crypto
00450     $ make OCTEON_TARGET=linux_64
00451 @endcode
00452 
00453 @section linux_user_checklist 8. Checklist for Simple Executive Programming
00454 
00455 -# Pointers and Hardware Addresses
00456  + In standalone simple executive applications, the underlying 1:1 TLB
00457   mapping allows applications to use hardware addresses and memory pointers
00458   interchangeably. This isn't true under Linux. Be sure
00459   to use cvmx_ptr_to_phys() and cvmx_phys_to_ptr() on addresses to/from
00460   hardware.
00461 -# POW
00462  + Be aware that getting work from the POW releases any atomic tag you
00463   currently have. If more than one thread of execution uses the POW, one
00464   may be expecting an atomic tag that was given away by the other thread.
00465   For example, if you are using the OCTEON kernel ethernet driver, it
00466   uses cores for packet processing. Any userspace app
00467   may find the POW state changing without notice. The ethernet
00468   driver will get work when a new packet interrupt is received. This
00469   interrupt has higher priority than user applications and forces a
00470   context switch. <b>POW TAG switches and deschedules cannot be used in
00471   userspace if the ethernet driver is loaded.</b>
00472 -# main() versus appmain()
00473  + Simple executive applications under Linux require the main entry point
00474   to be called @b appmain instead of @b main. The SDK examples use a
00475   @b -D compile directive to define main as an alias for appmain.
00476 -# Hardware initialization
00477  + Most hardware units can only be initialized once. Unless you carefully
00478   control initialization in your application, this means your userspace
00479   program can only be run once. For example, the SDK crypto example
00480   doesn't use much hardware and can run any number of times. On the other
00481   hand, the passthrough example reinitializes hardware on every run. It
00482   can only be run once.
00483 -# cvmx-interrupt, cvmx-uart
00484  + Userspace programs currently cannot use interrupts. Direct uart access
00485   is unwise. You should just use standard IO instead.
00486 -# Performance penalties
00487  + Although the OCTEON hardware has been configure to allow access to both
00488   hardware and memory without performance penalties, your application may
00489   still have a noticeable performance hit running under Linux. Due to
00490   larger amounts of code and data, cache misses and bus contention are
00491   more likely. The Linux scheduler timer interrupt also periodically
00492   transfers focus to other tasks. In real world usage, a simple
00493   executive application should have virtually the same performance
00494   characteristics as the standalone version.
00495 
00496 @section linux_user_passthrough 9. A detailed Simple Executive Port - Passthrough
00497 
00498 The process of porting a standalone simple executive application to Linux
00499 userspace should be fairly painless. Here we're going to highlight parts of
00500 the passthrough example specifically added for portability. Passthrough
00501 uses many of the OCTEON hardware widgets and still can run either
00502 standalone or under Linux.
00503 
00504 To start with, here is a list of headers used by passthrough:
00505 @code
00506 #include <stdio.h>
00507 #include <string.h>
00508 
00509 #include "cvmx-config.h"
00510 #include "cvmx.h"
00511 #include "cvmx-spinlock.h"
00512 #include "cvmx-fpa.h"
00513 #include "cvmx-pip.h"
00514 #include "cvmx-ipd.h"
00515 #include "cvmx-pko.h"
00516 #include "cvmx-dfa.h"
00517 #include "cvmx-pow.h"
00518 #include "cvmx-gmx.h"
00519 #include "cvmx-sysinfo.h"
00520 #include "cvmx-coremask.h"
00521 #include "cvmx-bootmem.h"
00522 #include "cvmx-helper.h"
00523 @endcode
00524 
00525 From this list you can imply that passthrough relies on the C library for
00526 IO and string / memory library functions. All other interfaces are supplied
00527 by the simple executive.
00528 
00529 A little further down in the code a few global shared variables are defined
00530 using CVMX_SHARED. Nothing special here, both Linux and standalone provide
00531 the CVMX_SHARED attribute for declaring variables shared between all cores
00532 running the application.
00533 
00534 @code
00535 static CVMX_SHARED uint64_t start_cycle;
00536 static CVMX_SHARED uint64_t stop_cycle;
00537 @endcode
00538 
00539 In application_main_loop passthrough loop receiving work. Here is the loop
00540 core with some extraneous code removed:
00541 
00542 @code
00543     // get the next packet/work to process from the POW unit.
00544     work = cvmx_pow_work_request_sync(0);
00545     // Begin packet output by requesting a tag switch to atomic.
00546     // Writing to a packet output queue must be synchronized across cores.
00547     cvmx_pow_tag_sw(work, work->ipprt, CVMX_POW_TAG_TYPE_ATOMIC);
00548 
00549     // Increment the total packet counts
00550     cvmx_fau_atomic_add64(FAU_PACKETS, 1);
00551     cvmx_fau_atomic_add64(FAU_OUTSTANDING, 1);
00552 
00553     // Build a PKO pointer to this packet
00554     pko_command.s.total_bytes = work->len;
00555     port = work->ipprt;
00556     packet_ptr = work->packet_ptr;
00557 
00558     cvmx_fpa_free(work, CVMX_FPA_WQE_POOL, 0);
00559 
00560     // Send the packet and wait for the tag switch to complete before
00561     // accessing the output queue. This ensures the locking required
00562     // for the queue.
00563     cvmx_pko_send_packet2(port, port, pko_command, packet_ptr);
00564 @endcode
00565 
00566 In this section of code all of the hardware to pointer conversions are
00567 performed automatically by the CVMX library. However, say we wanted to
00568 look at the data in the packet. @b packet_ptr->addr contains the hardware
00569 address of the first bytes of the packet. In the standalone case you might
00570 perform the following to get the first byte:
00571 
00572 @code
00573 uint8_t *ptr = (uint8_t *)packet_ptr->addr;
00574 uint8_t packet_byte = *ptr;
00575 @endcode
00576 
00577 This will fail under Linux. This is what should have been done:
00578 
00579 @code
00580 uint8_t *ptr = cvmx_phys_to_ptr(packet_ptr->addr);
00581 uint8_t packet_byte = *ptr;
00582 @endcode
00583 
00584 In order to produce statistics, passthrough needs to know how many cores
00585 ran the test. In the standalone simple executive case, you might assume
00586 all core are running the test. Instead passthrough uses the OCTEON
00587 instruction @b pop to count the bits in the sysinfo structure element
00588 core_mask.
00589 
00590 @code
00591 sysinfo = cvmx_sysinfo_get();
00592 coremask_passthrough = sysinfo->core_mask;
00593 ...
00594 int num_processors;
00595 CVMX_POP(num_processors, coremask_passthrough);
00596 @endcode
00597 
00598 Building passthrough for Linux requires a different library and linker
00599 script that the standalone case. Here is an example for each type of build:
00600 
00601 Standalone
00602 @code
00603 $ make
00604 @endcode
00605 
00606 Linux
00607 @code
00608 $ make OCTEON_TARGET=linux_64
00609 @endcode
00610 
00611 @section linux_user_files 10. Getting Files into the Filesystem
00612 
00613 Adding additional files to the embedded root filesystem can be accomplished
00614 in one of two ways. The first method is to add a config and makefile for it
00615 by following @ref linux_userspace_add_pkg. For quick testing purposes any
00616 files put in a directory can be added to the filesystem. Using
00617 "make menuconfig" in linux/embedded_rootfs, set
00618 <b>"Directory to copy extra files from"</b>.
00619 
00620 @section linux_user_bootmem 11. Allocating Non-virtual Memory
00621 
00622 Applications needing memory for direct use by hardware, or needing to
00623 bypass the virtual memory overhead of Linux may allocate memory using
00624 cvmx_bootmem_alloc(). This memory is global shareable and outside of the
00625 control of Linux. 64 bit applications can allocate large amounts of memory
00626 through this interface. 32 bit applications are limited to the amount set
00627 aside by CONFIG_CAVIUM_RESERVE32 in the Linux kernel config.
00628 
00629 @section linux_user_debugging 12. Debugging Tools
00630 
00631 The OCTEON Linux userspace environment includes GDB. See @ref linuxdebugger
00632 for more information.
00633 
00634 Kernel debugging can be accomplished using either KGDB
00635 or the Cavium Multicore debugger. See @ref linux_kernel_debugging for more
00636 information. 
00637 
00638 Simple executive applications can be debugged while under Linux.
00639 This is called inter-core debugging.  See @ref intercore_debugger for more
00640 information.  Using "make menuconfig" in linux/embedded_rootfs, set
00641 <b>octeon-debug-agent</b> and <b>Simple exec gdb</b>.
00642 
00643 @section linux_user_flash 13. Flash Access
00644 
00645 The flash chip soldered onto the EBT58XX development boards may be
00646 accessed using the /dev/mtd0 device. /dev/mtdblock0 supplies a
00647 standard block interface to this device. Be very careful when using
00648 this device, as it is capable of erasing the entire flash, including both
00649 the normal bootloader and the failsafe bootloader.
00650 
00651 @section linux_user_mass_storage_flash 14. Mass Storage Flash Devices
00652 
00653 @subsection linux_user_cf Compact Flash Access
00654 
00655 The EBT58XX compact flash interface can be accessed through /dev/sda*.
00656 Compact flashes should be mounted with:
00657 
00658 @verbatim
00659     mount -t vfat /dev/sda1 /mnt
00660 @endverbatim
00661 
00662 @subsection linux_user_mmc Multi-Media Card and Secure Digital (MMC/SD)
00663 
00664 The EBB6100, and some other boards, have MMC/SD interfaces that can be
00665 accessed through /dev/mmcblk*.  MMC/SD can be mounted with:
00666 with:
00667 
00668 @verbatim
00669     mount /dev/mmcblk0p1 /mnt
00670 @endverbatim
00671 
00672 @subsection linux_user_usb_ms USB Mass Storage Devices
00673 
00674 On systems with USB, standard USB mass storage devices are mounted in
00675 the usual manner.  The may be accessed through /dev/sd?*:
00676 
00677 @verbatim
00678     mount /dev/sda1 /mnt
00679 @endverbatim
00680 
00681 @section linux_user_serial 15. Serial Ports
00682 
00683 The two OCTEON serial ports are available as /dev/ttyS0 and /dev/ttyS1
00684 following the standard naming convention. The standard Linux @b stty
00685 can used to configure these ports.
00686 
00687 @note /dev/ttyS1 will not be available if debugging the kernel is enabled.
00688 Both KGDB and the OCTEON debugger reserve this port for kernel debugging
00689 when they are configured.
00690 
00691 @section linux_user_hugetlb 16. Optimizing virtual memory with HugeTLB support
00692 
00693 The OCTEON Linux kernel supports the HugeTLB extension and the hugetlbfs
00694 virtual filesystem. Applications needing large amounts of memory should
00695 use the HugeTLB extensions to improve TLB efficiency. Each HugeTLB can
00696 map large amounts of memory in a single entry. This can dramatically
00697 speedup applications using large amount of virtual memory. The following
00698 table shows the HugeTLB entry sizes for various kernel page sizes.
00699 
00700 <table>
00701     <tr><th>Kernel Pagesize</th><th>Huge TLB Pagesize</th><th>Number of normal pages saved</th></tr>
00702     <tr><td>4KB</td><td>2MB</td><td>512</td></tr>
00703     <tr><td>8KB</td><td>8MB</td><td>1024</td></tr>
00704     <tr><td>16KB</td><td>32MB</td><td>2048</td></tr>
00705     <tr><td>32KB</td><td>128MB</td><td>4096</td></tr>
00706     <tr><td>64KB</td><td>512MB</td><td>8192</td></tr>
00707 </table>
00708 
00709 @note For 64bit applications, memory allocated using cvmx_bootmem_alloc()
00710     bypasses the kernel virtual memory system. This memory doesn't require
00711     any dynamic TLB entries. Use cvmx_bootmem_alloc() for large blocks of
00712     memory not accessed using Linux system calls.
00713 
00714 In order to use HugeTLB support, you need to pass an additional parameter
00715 to the Linux kernel on boot. The parameter <b>hugepages=XXX</b> tells Linux
00716 how many HugeTLB entries to support. Note that HugeTLB memory blocks are
00717 allocated at boot and may not be used for other purposes. Once the kernel
00718 is booted with HugeTLB support, there are two different ways to allocate
00719 memory.
00720 
00721 The preferred method of allocating HugeTLB memory is with @b shmget(). Here
00722 is an example:
00723 
00724 @verbatim
00725     /*
00726        Example of using hugepage memory in a user application using Sys V shared
00727        memory system calls.  In this example the app is requesting 2MB of
00728        memory that is backed by huge pages.  The application uses the flag
00729        SHM_HUGETLB in the shmget system call to inform the kernel that it is
00730        requesting hugepages.
00731 
00732        For the ia64 architecture, the Linux kernel reserves Region number 4 for
00733        hugepages.  That means the addresses starting with 0x800000... will need
00734        to be specified.  Specifying a fixed address is not required on mip64,
00735        ppc64, i386 or x86_64.
00736 
00737        Note: The default shared memory limit is quite low on many kernels,
00738        you may need to increase it via:
00739 
00740        echo 268435456 > /proc/sys/kernel/shmmax
00741 
00742        This will increase the maximum size per shared memory segment to 256MB.
00743        The other limit that you will hit eventually is shmall which is the
00744        total amount of shared memory in pages. To set it to 16GB on a system
00745        with a 4kB pagesize do:
00746 
00747        echo 4194304 > /proc/sys/kernel/shmall
00748      */
00749     #include <stdlib.h>
00750     #include <stdio.h>
00751     #include <sys/types.h>
00752     #include <sys/ipc.h>
00753     #include <sys/shm.h>
00754     #include <sys/mman.h>
00755 
00756     #ifndef SHM_HUGETLB
00757     #define SHM_HUGETLB 04000
00758     #endif
00759 
00760     #define LENGTH (2UL*1024*1024) FIXME: Change this to match your Huge TLB Pagesize
00761 
00762     #define dprintf(x)  printf(x)
00763 
00764     /* Only ia64 requires this */
00765     #ifdef __ia64__
00766     #define ADDR (void *)(0x8000000000000000UL)
00767     #define SHMAT_FLAGS (SHM_RND)
00768     #else
00769     #define ADDR (void *)(0x0UL)
00770     #define SHMAT_FLAGS (0)
00771     #endif
00772 
00773     int main(void)
00774     {
00775         int shmid;
00776         unsigned long i;
00777         char *shmaddr;
00778 
00779         if ((shmid = shmget(2, LENGTH,
00780                     SHM_HUGETLB | IPC_CREAT | SHM_R | SHM_W)) < 0) {
00781             perror("shmget");
00782             exit(1);
00783         }
00784         printf("shmid: 0x%x\n", shmid);
00785 
00786         shmaddr = shmat(shmid, ADDR, SHMAT_FLAGS);
00787         if (shmaddr == (char *)-1) {
00788             perror("Shared memory attach failure");
00789             shmctl(shmid, IPC_RMID, NULL);
00790             exit(2);
00791         }
00792         printf("shmaddr: %p\n", shmaddr);
00793 
00794         dprintf("Starting the writes:\n");
00795         for (i = 0; i < LENGTH; i++) {
00796             shmaddr[i] = (char)(i);
00797             if (!(i % (1024 * 1024)))
00798                 dprintf(".");
00799         }
00800         dprintf("\n");
00801 
00802         dprintf("Starting the Check...");
00803         for (i = 0; i < LENGTH; i++)
00804             if (shmaddr[i] != (char)i)
00805                 printf("\nIndex %lu mismatched\n", i);
00806         dprintf("Done.\n");
00807 
00808         if (shmdt((const void *)shmaddr) != 0) {
00809             perror("Detach failure");
00810             shmctl(shmid, IPC_RMID, NULL);
00811             exit(3);
00812         }
00813 
00814         shmctl(shmid, IPC_RMID, NULL);
00815 
00816         return 0;
00817     }
00818 @endverbatim
00819 
00820 The older method of accessing HugeTLB memory is through the @b mmap
00821 interface of a file in the hugetlbfs filesystem. Below is an example using
00822 this method.
00823 
00824 @verbatim
00825     $ mount -t hugetlbfs none /mnt
00826 @endverbatim
00827 
00828 @verbatim
00829     /*
00830        Example of using hugepage memory in a user application using the mmap
00831        system call.  Before running this application, make sure that the
00832        administrator has mounted the hugetlbfs filesystem (on some directory
00833        like /mnt) using the command mount -t hugetlbfs nodev /mnt. In this
00834        example, the app is requesting memory of size 2MB that is backed by
00835        huge pages.
00836 
00837        For ia64 architecture, Linux kernel reserves Region number 4 for hugepages.
00838        That means the addresses starting with 0x800000... will need to be
00839        specified.  Specifying a fixed address is not required on mips64, ppc64,
00840        i386, or x86_64.
00841      */
00842     #include <stdlib.h>
00843     #include <stdio.h>
00844     #include <unistd.h>
00845     #include <sys/mman.h>
00846     #include <fcntl.h>
00847 
00848     #define FILE_NAME "/mnt/hugepagefile"
00849     #define LENGTH (2UL*1024*1024) FIXME: Change this to match your Huge TLB Pagesize
00850     #define PROTECTION (PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE)
00851 
00852     /* Only ia64 requires this */
00853     #ifdef __ia64__
00854     #define ADDR (void *)(0x8000000000000000UL)
00855     #define FLAGS (MAP_SHARED | MAP_FIXED)
00856     #else
00857     #define ADDR (void *)(0x0UL)
00858     #define FLAGS (MAP_SHARED)
00859     #endif
00860 
00861     void check_bytes(char *addr)
00862     {
00863         printf("First hex is %x\n", *((unsigned int *)addr));
00864     }
00865 
00866     void write_bytes(char *addr)
00867     {
00868         unsigned long i;
00869 
00870         for (i = 0; i < LENGTH; i++)
00871             *(addr + i) = (char)i;
00872     }
00873 
00874     void read_bytes(char *addr)
00875     {
00876         unsigned long i;
00877 
00878         check_bytes(addr);
00879         for (i = 0; i < LENGTH; i++)
00880             if (*(addr + i) != (char)i) {
00881                 printf("Mismatch at %lu\n", i);
00882                 break;
00883             }
00884     }
00885 
00886     int main(void)
00887     {
00888         void *addr;
00889         int fd;
00890 
00891         fd = open(FILE_NAME, O_CREAT | O_RDWR, 0755);
00892         if (fd < 0) {
00893             perror("Open failed");
00894             exit(1);
00895         }
00896 
00897         addr = mmap(ADDR, LENGTH, PROTECTION, FLAGS, fd, 0);
00898         if (addr == MAP_FAILED) {
00899             perror("mmap");
00900             unlink(FILE_NAME);
00901             exit(1);
00902         }
00903 
00904         printf("Returned address is %p\n", addr);
00905         check_bytes(addr);
00906         write_bytes(addr);
00907         read_bytes(addr);
00908 
00909         munmap(addr, LENGTH);
00910         close(fd);
00911         unlink(FILE_NAME);
00912 
00913         return 0;
00914     }
00915 @endverbatim
00916 
00917 @section linux_user_htlbremap 17. Using Htlbremap to optimize application memory
00918 
00919 @subsection linux_user_htlbremap_overview Overview
00920 
00921 <b>libhtlbremap.so</b> is a shared library that you can use to remap an
00922 application (text, data, heap and stack) into huge TLB pages.  This will
00923 significantly reduce the number of pages used by the application and thus
00924 the number of TLB refills needed.
00925 
00926 There is no need to rebuild the application.  You can use the Linux
00927 dynamic linkers LD_PRELOAD mechanism to load the shared library before
00928 your application would start.
00929 
00930 @note This approach only works with dynamicly linked applications.
00931 
00932 The library is part of the embedded root filesystem (@ref
00933 linux_userspace).  To invoke it run the application as usual except
00934 set the environment variable LD_PRELOAD to point to the
00935 libhtlibremap.so:
00936 
00937 @verbatim
00938     LD_PRELOAD=libhtlbremap.so application arg1 arg2 ...
00939 @endverbatim
00940 
00941 or
00942 
00943 @verbatim
00944     export LD_PRELOAD=libhtlbremap.so
00945     application arg1 arg2 ...
00946 @endverbatim
00947 
00948 @note The library is @b not part of the Debian file system.  To use it
00949 on Debian you can build it under
00950 $OCTEON_ROOT/linux/embedded_rootfs/source/htlbremap with a @b make.
00951 And then use the ABI-matching library with your program.  E.g. for the
00952 N64/default ABI:
00953 
00954 @verbatim
00955    export LD_PRELOAD=/path/to/libhtlbremap.so
00956    n64-appliation arg1 arg2 ...
00957 @endverbatim
00958 
00959 or for the N32 ABI (if your applicatoin builds with -mabi=n32):
00960 
00961 @verbatim
00962    export LD_PRELOAD=/path/to/libhtlbremap-n32.so
00963    n32-appliation arg1 arg2 ...
00964 @endverbatim
00965 
00966 When remapping the stack, htlbremap allocates memory for the stack.  The value
00967 set by ulimit -s is used if that provides a limit.  If the value is unlimited
00968 8MB of stack is allocated and beyond that the stack is grown using regular
00969 pages.
00970 
00971 @subsection linux_user_htlbremap_setup Setting up
00972 
00973 -# To set up huge TLB pages, first make sure hugetlbfs is mounted to
00974     /mnth.
00975     @verbatim
00976     mount -t hugetlbfs none /mnth
00977     @endverbatim
00978     @note If you use a different mount point, adjust the macro
00979     HTLB_FS_DIR in linux/embedded_rootfs/source/htlbremap/htlbremap.c
00980     accordingly.
00981 -# Set the contents of /proc/sys/vm/nr_hugepages to the maximum number
00982     of huge TLB pages.  Now /proc/meminfo should show to available
00983     number of huge TLB pages.
00984     @verbatim
00985     echo 50 > /proc/sys/vm/nr_hugepages
00986     @endverbatim
00987 -# Run your application.
00988     @verbatim
00989     LD_PRELOAD=libhtlbremap.so application arg1 arg2 ...
00990     @endverbatim
00991     @note Set the environment variable HTLBREMAP_DEBUG to a
00992     nonzero value to get debug messages.
00993 
00994 @subsection linux_user_htlbremap_options Controlling how htlbremap is run
00995 
00996 Through setting environment variables you can change some aspects of how htlbremap works.
00997 
00998       - HTLBREMAP_DEBUG: Set this if you want to see debug messages from
00999       htlbremap.
01000 
01001       - HTLBREMAP_DISABLE: Disable remapping of certain parts of memory.  This
01002       variable contains a list of strings: executable, heap, stack, or shlibs.
01003 
01004 @subsection linux_user_htlbremap_caveats Caveats
01005 
01006 -# When portions of an application's memory space are remapped with
01007     huge pages, all the remapped memory is made writable and
01008     executable.  This may be less memory protection than it had
01009     before the remapping.
01010 -# The libc default FILE buffers allocated by fopen() bypass the heap,
01011     and are allocated using direct calls to mmap() with the
01012     standard page size, thus bypassing the huge pages in the heap.
01013     Applications can override this behavior by calling setbuf() or
01014     setvbuf().
01015 -# If a process using libhtlbremap calls fork(), the system may have
01016     to allocate additional huge page to handle page copy-on-write
01017     requests.  This can lead to Out Of Memory (OOM) errors if the
01018     value of /proc/sys/vm/nr_hugepages is set too low.
01019 -# After remapping, /proc/NNN/maps will show the hugetlbfs file as the
01020     file for the executable and not the original.  This confuses
01021     oprofile as it assigns the PCs from the executable to the hugetlb
01022     file and it fails to map them to symbols producing incomplete data.
01023     The script htlb-fix-oprofile can help to fix up oprofile's internal
01024     representation to include the real executable rather than the
01025     hugetlbfs file.
01026 
01027 @section linux_user_schedtool 18. Controlling core affinity with schedtool
01028 
01029 Sometimes it is desirable to control which cpu core, or set of cores,
01030 an application can be scheduled to.  The Linux system call
01031 <b>sched_setaffinity</b> allows you to do this from code.  To make
01032 this generically easy from the command line, Cavium supplies the
01033 standard Linux utility <b>schedtool</b> which allows any shell command
01034 or currently executing process to be executed on any core or set of
01035 cores.
01036 
01037 @verbatim
01038 Usage: schedtool -a <cpu> -e <command>
01039        schedtool -a <mask> -e <command>
01040 @endverbatim
01041 
01042 <b>schedtool</b> starts the supplied command on a specific cpu or
01043 limits the command to running on the cpu's in the mask. "<cpu>" must
01044 be a decimal integer from 0..CPUS-1. "<mask>" must be a hexadecimal
01045 number specified as 0xXXXX. In both forms schedtool uses kernel virtual
01046 cpu numbering instead of the hardware physical numbers.  schedtool
01047 also allows process scheduling parameters to be set.  Consult
01048 schedtool's standard Linux man page for a full description of all the
01049 options.
01050 
01051 Here is an example:
01052 @verbatim
01053 schedtool -a 0 -e modprobe ethernet-pow
01054 @endverbatim
01055 
01056 */
Generated on 27 Oct 2017 for Octeon Software Development Kit by  1.6.1
